list.title: Question 4
list.content: Data scientists, web designers and developers are paid according to an $\text{industry}$ standard. The total annual salary spend for three tech startups paying to the industry standard are summarised in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39e56c4d-e2ed-4895-8314-4a98626d3fa9/images/51d9eae3-d31b-4473-ac07-bff89da9bf91/5881581baa8ab10a2984e4bc9a4c51bbabb53f5c.svg) Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the salaries, in thousand dollars, for data scientists, web designers and web developers respectively. - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represent the information in the table above. [2] - Using matrices, solve the system of linear equations from part (a) to determine the salaries for the three roles. [2] Data Quant is a tech startup that also pays to the industry standard and employs $10$ data scientists, $4$ web designers and $6$ web developers. - Calculate the exact value of the total salary bill for Data Quant. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
  x &+& 4y &+& 4z &=& 531.3 \\[3pt]
  8x &+& 2y &+& 5z &=& 1164 \\[3pt]
  4x &+& 5y &+& 10z &=& 1224.4
  \end{array}} \qref{(1)} \hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39e56c4d-e2ed-4895-8314-4a98626d3fa9/images/af6f2e62-ef6d-4814-8d70-04d899be2822/5bd3febb65c57b9290269b33685e039747728b41.svg)


  Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39e56c4d-e2ed-4895-8314-4a98626d3fa9/images/74d899b8-859b-4f8c-9f53-0442aab6f551/feafda106f57e3c9281f5952b79ab385ba004425.svg)


  Hence the salaries for the three roles are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Data Scientist}&: \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$96\hspace{0.15em}100} \\[6pt]
  \text{Web Designer}&: \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$49\hspace{0.15em}600} \\[6pt]
  \text{Web Developer}&: \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$59\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The total salary bill for Data Quant is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  10\times96\hspace{0.15em}100 + 4\times49\hspace{0.15em}600 + 6\times59\hspace{0.15em}200 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$1\hspace{0.15em}514\hspace{0.15em}600} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: The Brown, Miller and Taylor families pay utility bills for their houses each month. The table below shows the amount of electricity, water and gas consumed during January by each family, and the total cost of the utilities. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/0ed8b5d3-0b26-4aaa-9363-4388163154b1/4c79f485c80ba0239ecc4cfcc637b51df6e48bea.svg) Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the prices, in dollars, for $1$ kWh of electricity, $1$ m$^3$ of water and $1$ m$^3$ of gas, respectively. - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represents the information in the table above. [2] - Using matrices, find the price for each of the utility. [2] The Smith family also pay utility bills each month. The table below shows the amount of electricity, water and gas consumed during January by the Smith family. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/ddce5317-71bc-4d06-bd45-53079b3092f5/00ca88f1397a994795e3b84ae8c62e66b719b0b0.svg) - Calculate the total cost of the utilities for the Smiths. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
  950x &+& 72y &+& 448z &=& 343.59 \\[3pt]
  788x &+& 88y &+& 356z &=& 314.68 \\[3pt]
  532x &+& 49y &+& 298z &=& 219.43
  \end{array}} \qref{(1)} \hspace{0.6em}\end{aligned}

- If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/271993c3-62c6-4385-9f6a-69adee2c3fcd/30358a75db00011708b84ec520ef55df879b2a52.svg)


  Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/e9419910-5963-43c3-ae96-10010f32e1ea/d50fe173dd0736bf21c2972d4d6e6feec7a7d478.svg)


  Hence the prices for the utilities are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Electricity} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{10.5 \text{ cents per kWh}} \\[6pt]

  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Taste of Home Magazine recommends using a combination of Cheddar, Brie and Swiss when putting together cheese boards for parties. The recommended total cheese board size for a party of $10$ - $15$ people is $1$ kilogram. The table below shows the weight, in hundred of grams, of each kind of cheese required to make one kilogram of cheese combination, and the cost of making each combination. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/398066d9-a332-4209-90e9-4853461fb944/images/ce8d9594-1464-4833-a91b-37c05aab6a9c/1f95e531ff9a99fac83619dc0ed06ffca82c640c.svg) - By setting up a system of linear equations and using matrices, find the price per kilogram of each type of cheese. [2]

- Letting $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the cost per kilogram of Cheddar,
Brie and Swiss respectively, we have

  $$

  0.2x &+& 0.6y &+& 0.2z &=& 17.30 \\[3pt]
  0.5x &+& 0.2y &+& 0.3z &=& 12.30
  \end{array} \hspace{0.75em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}

  If we express

  Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/398066d9-a332-4209-90e9-4853461fb944/images/8263bf2a-264c-431f-bfdf-dc62abbf95aa/730c2a8cba4ad3132e7b19b40901796479a3143d.svg)


  Hence the prices of the three cheeses are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Cheddar} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$10.5 \text{ per kg}} \\[6pt]
  \text{Brie} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$22.5 \text{ per kg}} \\[6pt]

- The amount John spent on cheese is

  0.4\times10.5 + 0.2\times22.5 + 0.4\times8.50 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$12.1}\end{aligned}
  $$

If the car is at point $F$, it can move to point $B$, point $C$ or point $E$. - Choose the next point with random probability. For example, if the car is at point $C$, there is a $50\%$ chance it will move to point $D$ next and a $50\%$ chance it will move to point $F$. Justify your answer. [2]

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Two competing radio stations, station A and station B, each have $50$ % of the listener market at some point in time. Over each one-year period, station A $\text{manages}$ to take away $15$ % of station B's share, and station B manages to take away $10$ % of station A's share. - Write down a transition matrix that describes the exchange of market shares between the two stations over each one-year period. [1] - Find the market share held by each station after one year. [2] - Write down the market shares of stations A and B over a five-year period. [2] - Find the market share held by each station in the long term if the same trend of market share exchanges between the two stations continues indefinitely. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a6fb7c9-4391-4fb5-9f41-6bdfa489414a/images/54ffa861-6b38-4ff0-9b37-a8ef4660d3eb/39d56000058c2681fea79f631694890f33a2b8e2.svg)

  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Station A} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{0.525} \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  \text{Station B} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{0.475}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a6fb7c9-4391-4fb5-9f41-6bdfa489414a/images/b529b080-a804-4efc-81db-26b3c448cc95/96810039cd0f072be533e6164d111ed835e9f7da.svg)


- Let $a$ and $b$ be the market shares held by stations A and B in the

  We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a6fb7c9-4391-4fb5-9f41-6bdfa489414a/images/4b89e9a5-1e02-4513-9695-42f459376b1c/27c28d2d559359aa26e9e0b6e268d3c83cd7a82b.svg)


  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \begin{array}{rcl}
  \hspace{8.8em} a + b &=& 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{100\hspace{0.05em}\% of the market}] \\[6pt]
  0.10a - 0.15b &=& 0 
  \end{array} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

linear equations $(1)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}

  a &=& 0.6 \\[6pt]

  \end{array}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the market shares held by channels A and B in the long term
are

  $$

  \text{Station A} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{0.6} \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
